title: Introduction to Web Development
description: This is an entry level course for non-interactive digital media majors that introduces students to the process of managing online content as well as how to define the presentation styles and interaction modes for the user through the use of a content management system.

title: History of Web Development
description: This course explores all aspects of web development including the foundations of web technologies, formulation of web standards and how the individual web surfer's wants and needs have changed over time. Also discussed will be ground-breaking websites and the evolution of interface design for the web.

title: User Interface Design I
description: This course covers the design, prototyping, and evaluation of graphical user interfaces by exploring topics like human capabilities, input technologies, heuristic evaluation, and design methods, principles and rules. We will learn how to design aesthetically pleasing user interfaces, covering important design principles (learnability, visibility, error prevention, efficiency, and visual design) and the human capabilities that motivate them (including perception, motor skills, color vision, attention, and human error).

title: User Interface Design II
description: This course builds upon the topics covered in User Interface Design I by exploring advanced topics of graphical user interface design for desktop, mobile, and touch screen devices.

title: Interaction Design
description: This course is a study of interaction design. You will explore principles, patterns and process for interaction design, define the structure and behavior of interactive systems and how these can be used to create meaningful relationships between people and the products and services that they use.

title: Human Factors Engineering
description: Discusses ways of applying psychological and physiological principles to the design of interactive systems, products, processes, and systems to address human capabilities and limitations in ways that ensure safety, effectiveness, and ease of use.

title: User Experience Design I
description: In this course, students learn to identify and implement the elements required to create incredible digital experiences. Through the application of user-centered design practices, students will develop predictive and enjoyable designs based on a holistic consideration of users’ experience. Topics covered in this course include brand personality, research strategies, content strategy, information architecture, and usability.

title: User Experience Design II
description: This course focuses on taking prototypes from User Design I and creating fully functioning web apps. Students will create and execute a full production pipeline and learn to incorporate User Design practices along the way.

title: Web Design I
description: This course is a comprehensive overview of the design, creation, delivery and maintenance of functional, standards-based content on the Internet. Students will learn the aesthetics of web design alongside the underlying markup languages. They will critically evaluate web design quality, learn how to create and maintain quality web sites, and learn about accessibility and web design standards, and why they are important.

title: Web Design II
description: This course builds upon the topics covered in Web Authoring I by exploring advanced web development topics and current industry best practices.

title: Italian II
description: Continues ITAL 101.

title: Scripting for Interactive Digital Media I
description: This course explores modern client-side scripting languages that interact with the user, control the browser, communicate asynchronously, and alter document content and functionality.

title: Scripting for Interactive Digital Media II
description: This course explores modern server-side technologies for Internet based delivery of dynamic content that connect to and manipulate database content. Students learn how to build interactive, data-driven products.

title: Interactive Graphics
description: In this course, students learn how to use modern development techniques to create responsive and scalable two-dimensional graphics with support for interactivity and dynamic animation. Topics include styling and transforming vector graphics, raster graphics, and text where the implementation takes future growth into consideration.

title: Microinteractions
description: In this course, students learn to identify and implement the elements required to create incredible digital experiences. Through the application of user-experience design practices, students will develop predictive and enjoyable interactive designs based on a holistic consideration of users’ experience. Topics covered in this course include brand personality, content strategy, information architecture, and usability.

title: Web Game Design
description: Examines multimedia-authoring tools used to create interactive games. Students learn real world production techniques as they master advanced game design concepts.

title: Content Management Systems
description: Students set up a content management system and develop a custom theme. Includes project planning, organizing and maintaining a quality code base.

title: User Interface Design for Immersive Media
description: This course explores the nature of user interface design when applied to immersive media hardware, including Virtual Reality and Augmented Reality headsets.

title: WebVR
description: This course explores ways to deliver virtual reality experiences via a web browser.

title: Interactive App Design I
description: Focuses on creating user experiences optimized for mobile devices. Students learn to build unique web applications that take advantage modern mobile capabilities. Special consideration is given to limited screen real estate, low bandwidth Internet access, no Internet access, and touch screen devices.

title: Interactive App Design II
description: This course builds upon the topics covered in Mobile Interactive Design I by exploring how to convert web-based applications into cross-platform native applications for mobile devices. Special consideration is given to incorporating functionality that is currently unavailable in web-based applications.

title: Interactive App Design III
description: This course explores ways to deliver and test native mobile application prototypes using IDE’s (integrated Development Environments).

title: Interactive App Design IV
description: Learn how to build and test dynamic web application prototypes using event driven JavaScript languages.

title: Interactive Digital Media Workshop I
description: This course explores the developing or redesigning a successful interactive digital experience. Students work in team environments to analyze project requirements, develop a strategy for development, and utilize their design skills to present their findings to the client.

title: Interactive Digital Media Workshop II
description: This course builds upon the topics covered in Interactive Digital Media Workshop II by continuing to work in a team environment to building a high-fidelity interactive digital media prototype with a focus on usability testing.

title: Experimental Interactive Technologies
description: This course focuses on researching new innovations in experimental digital media technologies.

title: Internet of Things
description: This course uses an open approach to enable quick and seamless interactions with physical objects and locations via web protocols.

title: Professional Practices in Interactive Digital Media
description: This course will provide a broad overview of the practices of all areas included in the fields related to interactive digital media, including: organizational structure and roles, client communication and creative process, needs assessment, brief writing, brainstorming, concept development, pitches, pricing, proposals and presentations.

title: Validating Product Ideas
description: This course will teach you how to design, implement, and measure multichannel experiences with greater impact for customers, businesses, and society.

title: User Research Methodologies
description: Understanding the user is the fundamental backbone of User Experience Design. This course will teach students how to construct, implement and analyze user interviews in a way that will allow them to gain deep insights into their target audience.

title: Storytelling for User Experience Design
description: Students will learn how to use stories to understand the user, his/her goals and objectives, explain research, and describe design concepts.

title: Independent Study in Interactive Digital Media
description: Self-directed within the area of study requiring intermittent consultation with a designated instructor.
repeat_status: Can be repeated multiple times for credit

title: Italian III
description: Continues ITAL 102.

title: Visualization I: Computer Imaging
description: An introductory course that explores the use of proprietary computer applications for communications and the preparation of visual materials in Interior Design. The course introduces and reinforces classic design principles for expert visual communication of ideas through digital techniques from an Interior Design perspective.

title: History of Modern Architecture and Interiors
description: Covers development of modern architecture and interiors in the 19th and 20th centuries. Develops a vocabulary for discussing architecture; an understanding of how various factors affect design; and a familiarity with names, movements, and buildings that are part of historical development.

title: Textiles for Interiors
description: This course is a comprehensive introduction to textiles and their use in the interior design profession.
restrictions: Cannot enroll if classification is Freshman

title: Visualization II: Orthographic
description: This course explores design communication skills through hand drawing and model building exercises. Orthographic drawing skills are developed through investigation of plan, section, elevation and three dimensional drawings.

title: Environmental Design Theory
description: This course introduces design students to the relationship between people and the build environment. Understanding how people perceive, interact with, and are affected by their surroundings through readings and design exercieses make evident the significance of the psychological, pyshicological, social and cultural concepts of environmental behavior as an integral part of the designed environment.
restrictions: Cannot enroll if classification is Freshman

title: Structure
description: Investigates structure as an organizing principle in design by man and nature. Explores the basic objective and subjective relationships between form and function. Includes professionally juried presentations.

title: Visualization III: Digital
description: An intensive introduction to two and three dimensional drawing and visualization through the computer. This course explores orthographic and perspective drawing conventions and techniques from a digital perspective.

title: Visualization IV: 3D Modeling
description: An intensive introduction to advanced modeling and rendering software. Students will explore lighting, materiality, advanced form and spatial experience through realistic three-dimensional digital models.
restrictions: Cannot enroll if classification is Freshman

title: Interior Materials
description: Introduces basic construction materials and how they may be used successfully by the interior designer. Includes sample materials, visual aids, and guest speakers.
restrictions: Cannot enroll if classification is Freshman

title: Visual Culture: Interiors
description: Visual Culture: Interiors addresses the interior environment by studying the role history, economics, culture, materials and technological developments, impact decisions made by designers on interior spaces. While comparing historical context with specific knowledge, this course will enable the student to be a more articulate designer by a comprehensive examination of the interiors.
restrictions: Cannot enroll if classification is Freshman

title: Visual Culture: Furniture
description: An overview of furniture in relationship to interiors, and its influences reaching from the roots of antiquity to the impact of technology in today's products. It is the study of artifacts from various time periods and cultures in relation to social and political developments, life and work styles, visual arts, and economic influences.

title: Sustainability: History, Theory and Critic
description: Course examines the meaning and implications of sustainable design to develop an informed interpretation and working assessment of this movement. Concepts and methodologies are explored through assigned readings, class discussion, feild trips and team research.
restrictions: Cannot enroll if classification is Freshman

title: Interior Studio I
description: Foundation spatial course: Involves conscious recognition of the manipulation of space or spaces within a given volume and with a small-scale environmental orientation. Includes professionally juried presentations.

title: Interior Studio II
description: Primary spatial course. Involves conscious recognition of the manipulation of space or spaces within a given volume and small-scale environmental orientation. Includes professionally juried presentations.

title: Residential Design Studio
description: Provides experience with extensive real space. Emphasizes recognizing its aesthetic quality and maximizing its potential to meet the requirements of the inhabitants, by stylistic quality and elaboration in the selection and application of furniture finishes and accessories. Includes professionally juried presentations.
restrictions: Cannot enroll if classification is Freshman

title: Community Studio
description: Covers research, diagramming, site considerations, and program requirements for a specific user group; designing for complex spatial requirements with integration of interior components and furniture. Includes professionally juried presentations.

title: Visualization V: Methods
description: An advanced course in visualization for Interior Design. Hybrid representation strategies and specialized topics in digital and hand rendering will be covered.

title: Hospitality Design Studio
description: This course covers the design of commercial hospitality interiors. The studio project addresses program research and diagramming, site specificity, and designing for complex requirements with an awareness of vertical circulation, light, view, and enclosure. This course requires students to develop the ceiling plane and to create a visual identity for the design of restaurant interiors. This studio includes professionally juried presentations.

title: Interior Detailing
description: Covers basic considerations of interior construction and detailing and their application.

title: Interior Lighting
description: This course analyzes human needs and the perceptual responses of both general and special populations. It introduces the lighting design theory and principles and explores methods of creating mood and atmosphere with light. It develops vocabulary, documentation methods and understanding of energy conservation, lighting standards, and safety.

title: Collaborative Research in Sustainability
description: This cumulative course is the advanced students' opportunity to participate in a collaborative, interdisciplinary team in which the students will be applying sustainable technical and conceptual education in the context of 3rd party competitions, internally defined design challenges or applied research.
restrictions: Cannot enroll if classification is Freshman or Sophomore

title: Commercial Design Studio
description: Covers design of institutional-commercial interiors, including space planning, selection of materials and furnishings toward a synthesized environment, and development of specifications. Includes professionally juried presentations.
restrictions: Can enroll if classification is Junior or Senior.

title: Health & Wellness ID Studio
description: This studio addresses program and design requirements for a specific demographic community. It will prepare students to tackle the complex design problems that face the growing healthcare industry. The course focuses on an interdisciplinary approach to complex problems in the interior environment for the practice areas of health, healing, and well-being. Precedent studies, programming briefs, literature reviews, and collaborative teamwork are used to create evidence-based design solutions that incorporate creativity, human factors data, user-centered design approach, life-safety codes, and building codes. This studio includes professionally juried presentations.

title: Furniture Design
description: Covers design of environmental elements, simultaneous concerns with craftsmanship and the application of materials to ideas, and development of prototypes. A lab fee is required for this course.
repeat_status: Can be repeated 2 times for 13 credits
restrictions: Can enroll if classification is Junior or Senior.

title: Contract Documentation for Interior Design
description: Provides an understanding of the basic procedures and techniques for the development of construction drawings and furniture documentation. Requires students to use case studies to produce a set of drawings representative of current interior design industry standards.
restrictions: Can enroll if classification is Junior or Senior.

title: Professional Practice
description: Surveys contemporary business methods, practices, and procedures in the operation of a design firm, including legal and ethical implications. Examines these practices through case studies and lectures by design professionals.
restrictions: Can enroll if classification is Junior or Senior.

title: Interior Systems
description: Introduces building systems, mechanical, electrical, ceiling and furniture systems, and their effect on the interior environment. Includes visual aids and guest speakers.
restrictions: Can enroll if classification is Junior or Senior.

title: Competition Studio
description: Competition opportunities from regional to international from professional to philanthropic allow for investigations of diverse contemporary issues surrounding the built environment. Students work under direction of a faculty member(s) to discuss, explore and develop solutions for entry into noteworthy competitions.
repeat_status: Can be repeated 1 times for 6 credits
restrictions: Can enroll if classification is Junior or Senior.

title: Senior Project I
description: Part one of the 3-term senior project where students develop a capstone independent design project from concept, research and programming to complete design development.
restrictions: Can enroll if major is INTR.

title: Senior Project II
description: Part two of the 3-term senior project where students develop a capstone independent design project from concept, research and programming to complete design development.
restrictions: Can enroll if major is INTR.

title: Senior Project III
description: Part three of the 3-term senior project where students develop a capstone independent design project from concept, research and programming to complete design development.
restrictions: Can enroll if major is INTR.

title: Independent Study in Interior Design
description: Self-directed within the area of study requiring intermittent consultation with a designated instructor.
repeat_status: Can be repeated multiple times for credit

title: Independent Study in Interior Design
description: Self-directed within the area of study requiring intermittent consultation with a designated instructor.
repeat_status: Can be repeated multiple times for credit

description: Self-directed within the area of study requiring intermittent consultation with a designated instructor.
repeat_status: Can be repeated multiple times for credit

repeat_status: Can be repeated multiple times for credit

title: Special Topics in Interior Design
description: Topics decided upon by faculty will vary within the area of study.
repeat_status: Can be repeated multiple times for credit

repeat_status: Can be repeated multiple times for credit

title: Special Topics in Interior Design
description: Topics decided upon by faculty will vary within the area of study.
repeat_status: Can be repeated multiple times for credit

title: Special Topics in Interior Design
description: Topics decided upon by faculty will vary within the area of study.
repeat_status: Can be repeated multiple times for credit

title: University Chorus
description: A large chorus that studies and performs music of many styles; performs each term. May be repeated for credit.
repeat_status: Can be repeated multiple times for credit

title: Chamber Singers
description: A select choir that performs advanced choral repertoire; performs frequently on and off campus. May be repeated for credit.
repeat_status: Can be repeated multiple times for credit

title: Naturally Sharp (Vocal Jazz Ensemble)
description: Naturally Sharp is a select group of singers, chosen by audition in the fall from the University Chorus. Naturally Sharp performs vocal jazz repertoire from the past hundred years with a three-piece backup band. Singers must also be able to do solos.
repeat_status: Can be repeated multiple times for credit

title: All-College Choir
description: All-College Choir is a non-auditioned, mixed voice ensemble that performs repertoire of various styles, genres and eras - including music of the classical tradition, jazz, spirituals, American musical theater, folk and pop.
repeat_status: Can be repeated multiple times for credit

title: Concert Band
description: Performs a wide variety of music written for a large band; concerts given each term. May be repeated for credit.
repeat_status: Can be repeated multiple times for credit

title: Guitar Ensembles
description: Performs a wide variety of music written for a small guitar ensemble; concerts given at least twice a year. May be repeated for credit.
repeat_status: Can be repeated multiple times for credit

title: Jazz Ensembles
description: Offers rehearsal, study, and performance of jazz compositions for both large and small ensembles; concerts given on and off campus, sometimes with guest soloists. May be repeated for credit.
repeat_status: Can be repeated multiple times for credit

title: Jazztet
description: Jazztet is a subset of the larger Jazz Orchestra. Its size can vary based upon the availability of instrumentation and the desire of the director. Its purpose is to present jazz music in a small instrumentation format. Performances are typically part of the greater Jazz Orchestra concerts at the end of each term.
repeat_status: Can be repeated multiple times for credit

title: University Orchestra
description: This is a full orchestra that performs concert repertoire of various periods from the 18th century to the present day. Wind, brass, and percussionists must be in the concert band in order to participate.
repeat_status: Can be repeated multiple times for credit

title: Keyboard Ensembles
description: Performs a wide variety of music written for a small keyboard ensemble; concerts given at least twice a year. May be repeated for credit.
repeat_status: Can be repeated multiple times for credit

title: Chamber Music Ensemble
description: Various small ensembles performing a variety of music of many periods and styles. May be repeated for credit.
repeat_status: Can be repeated multiple times for credit

title: Fusion Band
description: Performs a wide variety of music written for a small fusion ensemble. The Fusion Band gives concerts at least twice a year. May be repeated for credit.
repeat_status: Can be repeated multiple times for credit

title: Percussion Ensembles
description: Performs a wide variety of music written for a small percussion ensemble. The ensemble gives concerts at least twice a year. May be repeated for credit.
repeat_status: Can be repeated multiple times for credit

title: Mediterranean Ensemble
description: The Drexel University Mediterranean Ensemble is open to any student with an interest in performing traditional music from the Balkans, the Middle East and Northern Africa. All instruments are welcomed.
repeat_status: Can be repeated multiple times for credit

title: Gospel Choir
description: Performs gospel music drawn from both traditional and contemporary sources. Performance opportunities for both singers and instrumentalists. Concerts given on and off campus each term. May be repeated for credit.
repeat_status: Can be repeated multiple times for credit

title: Pep Band
description: Pep Band is a group of roughly forty-five student musicians primarily from the concert band. The purpose of the Pep Band is to support the Drexel Dragons basketball team and play from the bleachers at home games as well as travel to tournaments.
repeat_status: Can be repeated multiple times for credit

title: Rock Ensemble
description: Rock Ensemble is an ensemble where students have the opportunity to gain experience working as a group rehearsing, arranging, organizing, recording, and ultimately performing songs in the rock/pop/contemporary genres. By choosing music that is both of high quality and varied, students have a unique opportunity to develop a strong work ethic while being exposed to various musical challenges.
repeat_status: Can be repeated multiple times for credit

title: Chamber Music: Strings
description: MUSC 118 forms its participants into various sized string groups from trios and quartets to octets. The repertoire spans music of the classical tradition and beyond, from the modern day back to the 17th century. These small groups will perform as part of a larger chamber recital at the end of each term.
repeat_status: Can be repeated multiple times for credit

title: Music Fundamentals
description: Music Fundamentals teaches students essential skills and knowledge relating to Western music. Focus is placed on ear training and core music theory concepts. This course perfectly compliments any student’s musical playing ability, beginning to advanced, and is essential to further musical development.

title: Music Theory I
description: MUSC 121 covers the foundations of: notation, major/minor scales and keys, intervals, chord construction, phrase construction, small forms, and basic techniques of harmonizing a melody. The methodology centers on analysis combined with application.

title: Music Theory II
description: MUSC 122 covers: texture and textural reduction, chromatic harmony, modulation, and large forms. This is a continuation of MUSC 121 and provides more depth into the topics of that course as well as offers advanced material. The methodology combines musical analysis with application.

title: Jazz Theory
description: Jazz Theory introduces musical concepts and skills as they pertain to this specific style of music. The material discussed is foundational knowledge for jazz composition, arranging, and improvisation. Therefore, this course is suitable for students interested in jazz performance or composition.

title: Ear Training I
description: Introduces the basics of ear training and sight singing.

title: Ear Training II
description: Continues MUSC 125.

title: Introduction to Music
description: Provides an introduction to music, including elements of melody, harmony, rhythm, texture, structure, history, and an introduction to various genres. Emphasizes listening with understanding.

title: Mambo, Samba, Salsa, and More
description: This course introduces the various Latin American musical traditions, as well as their historical contexts, evolution, inter-connectivity and current importance.

title: Survey of Songwriting
description: This course will examine the art and craft of songwriting. Students will listen to and analyze many examples from folk and popular music, from the 1930’s through to the present day. Students will use this knowledge, as well as that of basic music fundamentals, to compose a song at the end of the term.

title: Class Piano I
description: Uses a group situation to teach basic performance skills and beginning instruction on piano.

title: Class Guitar I
description: Uses a group situation to teach basic performance skills and beginning instruction on guitar.

title: Class Percussion I
description: Uses a group situation to teach basic performance skills and beginning instruction on percussion.

title: Class Voice I
description: Uses a group situation to teach basic performance skills and beginning instruction in voice.

title: Class Bass I
description: Class Bass I uses group instruction to teach basic performance skills and techniques on electric bass guitar and upright bass.
repeat_status: Can be repeated 3 times for 6 credits

title: Class Bass II
description: Class Bass II uses group instruction to teach advanced performance skills and techniques on electric bass guitar and upright bass.
repeat_status: Can be repeated 3 times for 6 credits

title: Jazz Class Piano
description: Students will learn the fundamentals in jazz piano playing by studying the melodic, harmonic and rhythmic aspects associated with jazz. Students will learn how to read, “lead sheets” and improvise over modal and standard chord changes.

title: Modern Arranging Techniques
description: Modern Arranging Techniques. Discusses the capabilities and ranges of varying instruments. Students study modern arranging techniques utilizing strategies and standard music material.

title: European Classical Music History
description: This course surveys and analyzes compositions from antiquity through the modern period in European music history. After an overview of musical vocabulary, we will study selected masterpieces of Western music, thereby gaining a greater appreciation for developments of musical style.

title: European Classical Music History II
description: This course surveys and analyzes compositions from the Romantic Era through the 21st Century in European classical music history.

title: The Beatles
description: This course will examine the cultural phenomena of The Beatles from their early history as a band through the end of their regular collaboration in 1970. While The Beatles have been examined in many different ways, this course will concentrate on their productivity as a rock band through the single pop song, the pop album, and film. It will also serve to provide a more in depth study of the group and their influence on other popular culture.

title: History of Film Music
description: This course surveys film music from the silent film era to the present. Topics will include the composers of the genre, the changing musical styles through the decades, and the techniques used by film composers.

title: Rock Music Through the Mid-60s
description: Surveys rock music from its roots through the mid-60s.

title: Rock Music Since the Mid-60s
description: Surveys rock music from the mid-60s through the mid-90s.

title: Private Lesson
description: Weekly private music lessons on an instrument or voice as indicated by the section number. Lessons are fifty minutes per week. The specific day and time is mutually agreed upon by the instructor and the student. Musical style, level of ability, and learning objectives are individually based. Students are encouraged to contact the instructor if they have questions. Students are charged a lab fee every term they register.
repeat_status: Can be repeated multiple times for credit

title: Digital Music Composition
description: Digital Music Composition teaches students how to compose music intended to be produced by a computer and related to software, opposed to composing for acoustic instruments. Students will learn how to use specific music software and explore contemporary compositional techniques.

title: Music Composition
description: Music Composition engages students in writing music for ensembles ranging from solo performer to large ensemble. Techniques of the common practice period as well as modernist harmonic techniques will be introduced and applied. Live performance of student projects will be provided and is an important feature of the course.

title: Class Piano II
description: Class Piano II is a continuation of Class Piano I. By the end of the term students will be able to perform a number of simple songs, play several scales and chord progressions, and have basic note reading skills.

title: Class Guitar II
description: Class Guitar II is a continuation of Class Guitar I. In this course students continue to work on note reading in first position, develop rhythmic skills and reading ability in different keys, learn movable barred chords and power chords, and learn basic finger picking technique.

title: Improvisation
description: Provides study and practice of various improvisatory styles in music. Includes classroom lectures, listening, and solo and ensemble performance.

title: Songwriting
description: Addresses basic songwriting techniques including form, melody, rhythm, lyrics, and production. Projects are required.

title: World Musics
description: Surveys various musical traditions from around the world in their cultural contexts. Includes selected music from Africa, the Americas, Europe, South Asia, Southeast Asia, Northeast Asia, West Asia, and Oceania.

title: Special Topics in Performing Arts
description: Topics decided upon by faculty will vary within the area of study.
repeat_status: Can be repeated multiple times for credit

title: Afro-American Music USA
description: Examines the African heritage and related New World forms outside the United States. Covers work songs, spirituals, blues, folk music, ragtime, gospel, rhythm and blues, jazz, etc.

title: The Power of Black American Music
description: Provides an overview of American Folk music established by Black Americans in the early 1600s. Attention will be given to the African and Caribbean heritage exploring the religious, economic, cultural, and social environment that gave birth to work songs, spirituals, ragtime, blues, jazz, country, gospel, rock ‘n’ roll, rhythm & blues, soul, and hip hop. The course provides the opportunity to listen to music and highlight the musical inventions Black Americans brought to the new world.

title: History of Jazz
description: Surveys the music popularly known as jazz from before 1900 through the stylistic changes and trends of the 20th century. Covers precursors, early jazz, big bands, bebop, the new music, etc.

title: Hip-Hop Music History
description: Hip-Hop Music History is a comprehensive exploration of the origins of hip-hop music, and its meteoric rise to a preeminent genre of popular American music today. Instruction for this course comprises of the examination of hip-hop's noteworthy practitioners, the corroborative technology and propitious media which support it, and the often innovative practice of musical and lyrical creativity that defines the genre.

title: American Popular Music
description: Examines popular music (dances, marches, ragtime, jazz, musical comedy, movie music, swing, rock, etc.) from Colonial times to the present, with cultural-historical contexts.

title: Applied Music-Recital
description: Students will present a public recital featuring significant solo repertoire. Repertoire choices for recital must be made through the Applied Music instructor.

title: Independent Study in Music
description: Self-directed within the area of study requiring intermittent consultation with a designated instructor.
repeat_status: Can be repeated multiple times for credit

title: Independent Study in Music
description: Self-directed within the area of study requiring intermittent consultation with a designated instructor.
repeat_status: Can be repeated multiple times for credit

repeat_status: Can be repeated multiple times for credit

title: Special Topics in Music

repeat_status: Can be repeated multiple times for credit

title: Special Topics in Music
description: Topics decided upon by faculty will vary within the area of study.
repeat_status: Can be repeated multiple times for credit

title: Survey of the Music Industry
description: This course provides students with an overview of the music industry. The following topics will be addressed: major music industry players (e.g. managers, agents, business managers, promoters), record label operations & functions (e.g. recording deals, royalties, the album cycle), Songwriting/Publishing, Live Music/Touring, & Merchandising.
restrictions: Can enroll if major is MUSI.

title: Audio Production I
description: The objective of this course is to develop an understanding of the best practices of using a Digital Audio Workstation to create a music project. The class will be a combination of lecture modules and in-class hands-on practice.
restrictions: Can enroll if major is MUSI.

title: Copyrights in the Music Industry
description: This course is an in-depth exploration of what, how, when and where intellectual property exists in the music industry, with a particular emphasis on the role that copyrights play.
restrictions: Can enroll if major is MUSI.

title: Introduction to Sound Recording
description: This course introduces the art of sound recording, including the fundamentals of sound, sound capture, acoustic environments, and recording technology.
restrictions: Can enroll if major is MUSI.

title: Audio Systems
description: This course explores the fundamentals of sound capture, audio signals, audio devices, sound systems, and signal interconnections.

title: Listening Techniques
description: Students will develop critical listening skills needed for all aspects of music production including commercial arranging, tracking, and mixing.
restrictions: Can enroll if major is MUSI.

title: Audio Production II
description: This course will help students develop proficiency in using Pro Tools for advanced music production and sound editing tasks. By engaging in hands-on exercises, lectures, and collaborative projects, students will acquire a comprehensive understanding of advanced recording, editing, and mixing techniques within the Pro Tools environment.
restrictions: Can enroll if major is MUSI.

title: Live Music I
description: This course will cover the various business aspects of producing and promoting successful tours and concerts. The class will place emphases and cover in great detail: (1) the promoter’s ability to purchase talent and produce shows, taking into consideration such matters as competition, population, guarantees and percentage splits, ticket pricing and distribution, advertising budgets, production costs, sponsorships, rental agreements, labor, security, concessions, tour packages, and promoter-owned venues; and (2) managing and producing a tour, focusing on a tour theme and marketing plan, routing, itineraries, riders, offers, contracts, sub-contractors, show and tour personnel, merchandising, sponsorships, day-of-show and show settlements.
restrictions: Can enroll if major is MUSI.

title: Special Topics in Performing Arts
description: Topics decided upon by faculty will vary within the area of study.
repeat_status: Can be repeated multiple times for credit

title: Marketing in the Music Industry I
description: This course aims to provide students with a comprehensive understanding of the foundations of marketing and promotion in the music industry, including the essential concepts, strategies, and tactics used by artists and music professionals to create impactful campaigns.

title: Sound Recording for Business Concentration
description: Sound recording techniques are presented to provide Music Industry Business Concentration students with basic recording competency through practical application. Students are required to create several recordings through projects that require teamwork and self-analysis.
restrictions: Can enroll if major is MUSI.

title: Sound Recording I
description: Basic sound recording procedures are presented with an emphasis on microphone techniques, signal-flow, and session workflow. Requires students to create several multitrack recordings, including editing and mixing.
restrictions: Can enroll if major is MUSI. Cannot enroll if classification is Freshman

title: Record Label Operations
description: This course is a general overview of record label operations including the different roles at labels, different types of labels, and how the role of labels have changed over time.

title: Streaming and Radio Promotion
description: This course provides an overview of how radio and music streaming is used in record promotion and artist development and includes both theory and practical applications.

title: Community Recording
description: Community Recording is an enterprise designed to foster empowerment and self-expression through music. It brings members of the Mantua, Powelton, and Drexel communities together to create a sustainable creative collective that produces and releases music and shares knowledge and techniques.

title: Survey of Music Production
description: This course analyzes various music recordings, including the genres of jazz, pop, R&B, and rock, from the modern recording era (1930’s to the present) and discusses the production techniques used to create them.
restrictions: Can enroll if major is MUSI.

title: Music Merchandising
description: Students work in interdisciplinary groups with Design and Merchandising students to create a comprehensive merchandise extension program including product selection, production, distribution and promotion within the context of the artists' overall brand package.

title: Live Music II
description: This course will cover the various business aspects of producing and promoting a successful concert. The class will place emphases and cover in great detail: the promoter’s ability to purchase talent and a produce show, taking into consideration such matters as competition, population, guarantees and percentage splits, ticket pricing and distribution, advertising budgets, production costs, sponsorships, rental agreements, labor, security, concessions, tour packages, and promoter-owned venues; routing, itineraries, riders, offers, contracts, sub-contractors, show personnel, merchandising, sponsorships, day-of-show and show settlements.
restrictions: Can enroll if major is MUSI.

title: Audio Production III
description: This course will develop students' understanding of digital audio and MIDI production techniques using Ableton Live by integrating in-class demonstrations, lectures, and hands-on projects and activities. Through these methods, students will acquire a comprehensive understanding of Ableton Live's capabilities and develop practical skills using this software to create high-quality audio productions.
restrictions: Can enroll if major is MUSI.

title: Contracts and Legal Issues in the Music Industry
description: This course explores contractual agreements and the legal issues affecting the music industry today, such as free speech in radio and music lyrics, rights of publicity for recording artists, fair use and piracy, as well as the various standard agreements in common use in the music and recording industries.
restrictions: Can enroll if major is MUSI.

title: Audio Seminar
description: Students present Extra Curricular recording projects to the instructor and fellow students for an in-class critique. The in-class critique will give the student direct feedback on their creative work and allow them to compare their work against the work of their peers. The production critiques will be moderated by the instructor and grades will be assessed based on in-class participation and presentations.
repeat_status: Can be repeated 1 times for 4 credits
restrictions: Can enroll if major is MUSI.

title: Live Music III
description: This course builds on the fundamental relationships in the concert business, from the technical and artistic aspects of concert promotion learned in Live Music II and introduces music tour planning. Students will examine how to hire employees for tour, create budgets, negotiate contracts, promote a tour and the logistics of tour production, marketing and managing government regulations, that in the end, will maximize revenue over multiple shows. Additionally, students will examine the effects of touring over extended times vs single shows, for artists and their touring parties.
restrictions: Can enroll if major is MUSI.

title: Artist Development
description: This course introduces concepts including what an A&R rep does, historically and today; artist development in the major label and independent markets; and A&R methods using industry data.

title: Music Publishing
description: This course explores the fundamental responsibilities of a music publisher including reviewing, evaluating, marketing, licensing, monetizing, representing and protecting original music, as well as the rights of songwriters and related content creators. Students will discover how music publishing is a crucial element of support in a thriving music industry and will learn how music publishers build value for their creative clients.
restrictions: Can enroll if major is MUSI.

title: Cities of Music and Culture
description: This course is designed to give students an introductory insight and understanding of the music industry in the chosen location of the class. This class is a Study Tour.

title: Music Supervision
description: Students will be introduced to the creative and administrative elements of music supervision including sourcing, evaluating, licensing, and placing music into visual productions.
restrictions: Can enroll if major is MUSI.

title: Entrepreneurship in the Music Industry
description: Students will learn how to devise, conceive, create and implement a music industry-related business through the drafting of a business plan. This course is team-driven and will involve student discussions and critique.
restrictions: Can enroll if major is MUSI.

title: Marketing in the Music Industry II
description: Building on the foundations of Marketing in the Music Industry I, this course provides students with an advanced and applied understanding of the strategies and tactics used to promote music and music-related content across different channels and through various forms of media. Students will utilize insights-driven reasoning, creative ideation, and critical thinking to solve marketing challenges, meet promotional objectives, and drive engagement with target audiences. This course is team-driven and involves extensive student discussions, critique, and group project work in and outside of the classroom.
restrictions: Can enroll if major is MUSI.

title: MAD Dragon Music Group
description: MAD Dragon Music Group is designed to immerse students in the world of the independent music business and includes all of the professor led, student operated enterprises that create, organize and administer MAD Dragon Music Group projects.
repeat_status: Can be repeated 2 times for 9 credits

title: Sound Recording II
description: An advanced examination of current state of the art sound recording techniques. Special attention is paid to concert recording, digital and analog mixing techniques, advanced compression and equalization techniques, and time-based processing. Research methods in sound are introduced.
restrictions: Can enroll if major is MUSI and classification is Junior or Pre-Junior or Senior.

title: Audio for Video
description: This course will introduce the student to the technological and creative aspects of creating post-production audio for visual media.
restrictions: Can enroll if major is MUSI.

title: Scoring to Picture
description: This course will expand the students' ability to create and produce an original score for an audio/visual element, drawing upon their creative and technological skills.
restrictions: Can enroll if major is MUSI. Cannot enroll if classification is Freshman

title: Synthesis and Sampling
description: The primary goal of this course is to provide students with a comprehensive understanding of synthesis and sampling techniques used in contemporary music production. Throughout the course, students will develop practical skills and knowledge related to various synthesis techniques, sound design, and the creative application of sampling, ultimately enabling them to produce innovative and high-quality audio elements for various musical genres and projects.
restrictions: Can enroll if major is MUSI.

title: Studio Maintenance
description: Introduces the student to basic maintenance and troubleshooting techniques used in the modern recording studio. Basic electronic components, cabling, soldering skills, audio measurements, and equipment calibration are emphasized.
restrictions: Can enroll if major is MUSI.

title: Production Company Management
description: Students will research the basic financial, business, marketing, and networking practices of successful freelancers in the music industry and explore career development strategies to thrive in the music industry gig economy.
restrictions: Can enroll if major is MUSI. Cannot enroll if classification is Freshman or Sophomore

title: Live Sound I
description: This course covers all aspects of sound reinforcement for live performances, including system design, equipment usage, and acoustical concerns. The course uses both lecture and hands-on components for greater student understanding.

title: Analog Recording
description: This class enables students to practice the art of analog recording, editing and mixing. It puts in perspective the concepts, tools, and techniques of studio production that can be taken for granted in the digital domain. The constraints and aesthetic choices that are magnified by the analog format are very important parts of a holistic music production curriculum.
restrictions: Can enroll if major is MUSI and classification is Junior or Senior.

title: Live Sound II
description: This course is an examination of current state-of-the-art sound reinforcement techniques. Special attention is paid to system design and optimization, digital mixing console operation, wireless systems, and concert recording.

title: Music Industry Data Analytics
description: Through this course, students will gain a deep understanding of the role of data in the business of music, balancing theoretical concepts, illustrative case studies, and practical application.
restrictions: Can enroll if major is MUSI.

title: Innovation in the Modern Music Industry
description: This course studies the profound evolution of the music industry by examining entrepreneurial and technological innovation in the post-Napster era. Through in-depth discussions, critical analysis, and collaborative projects, students will gain insight into the cultural, business, and creative transformations driving today’s music landscape, as well as their own potential to contribute to future industry innovation.
restrictions: Cannot enroll if classification is Freshman or Sophomore

title: Global Recording Business
description: This course is designed to give students a global perspective of the recording business. Students will research individual markets and compare and contrast them in order to evaluate business conditions and consider future economic prospects.
restrictions: Can enroll if major is MUSI.

title: Audio for Media II
description: This course will present advanced concepts and techniques utilized for creating post-production audio for video, television, and film. Students will also explore other current and future media, such as gaming and VR/XR/MR (virtual reality, extended reality, and mixed reality).

title: Photography
description: Lecture-laboratory course in black and white photography. With a combination of lectures, assignments and group critiques, students learn to see photographically through an exploration of the basic tools, techniques and aesthetics of photography. For PHTO Majors, a manual 35mm film camera is required. For PHTO Minors & non-majors a digital point and shoot camera or DSLR, 16 megapixels or greater is required. Cameras that are capable of shooting in RAW format are strongly recommended.

title: Audio Production IV
description: In this course, students will gain in-depth knowledge of advanced vocal and drum production techniques using Pro Tools, Ableton Live and Logic Pro. The course is structured around weekly studio sessions and hands-on learning experiences, covering a wide range of topics from vocal recording, and editing to drum replacement and multi-DAW production. Throughout the course, students will have the opportunity to work on various aspects of audio production, including vocal coaching, comping, tuning, alignment, repair, and mixing. Additionally, students will be introduced to multi-DAW production workflows and the process of creating multitrack and stems for mixing and mastering purposes.
restrictions: Can enroll if major is MUSI.

title: Artist Management
description: This course examines the components that comprise an artist's professional team. The course will explore and analyze the central role that managers, attorneys, agents, business managers, services firms, record labels and other entities each play in representing, developing, and supervising the artist’s overall business and brand.
restrictions: Can enroll if major is MUSI. Cannot enroll if classification is Freshman

title: Music Industry Colloquium
description: Students will be exposed to state-of-the-art research and industry experience from practitioners and researchers from the local and national stage. This course requires weekly participation in the department colloquium.
repeat_status: Can be repeated 3 times for 4 credits

title: Music Production
description: The students in this class learn contemporary music production techniques through a combination of lecture, demonstration and independent work.
restrictions: Can enroll if major is MUSI.

title: Mixing
description: This is an advanced audio engineering course that will focus on the technical and creative processes of mixing. Proper equipment usage, methods, formats, and production goals for various genres of music are covered.
restrictions: Can enroll if major is MUSI.

title: Mastering
description: This course explores the various technical processes involved in professional audio mastering, including dynamic range control, spectral balancing, distortion, and noise detection.

title: Music Industry Research Methods
description: This course is a general overview of research methods used in the music industry. The course presents a conceptual basis for designing research and assessing research quality and illustrates these concepts through in-depth reviews of research areas, including (1) qualitative studies, (2) surveys and (3) experiments. The course also touches on basic descriptive statistics, inferential statistics and measures of association. This is a writing intensive course.

title: Senior Project in Music Industry
description: Senior Project is a thesis course in which student groups engage over two quarters of senior year in intensive research on a topic selected by a jury among individual proposals. The thesis will result in some form of publishable material.
repeat_status: Can be repeated 2 times for 9 credits
restrictions: Can enroll if major is MUSI and classification is Senior.

title: Directed Studies in Music Industry
description: Provides supervised individual study of special topics in the music industry. Departmental permission required.
repeat_status: Can be repeated multiple times for credit
restrictions: Can enroll if major is MUSI.

title: Independent Study in Music Industry Program
description: Self-directed within the area of study requiring intermittent consultation with a designated instructor.
repeat_status: Can be repeated multiple times for credit

repeat_status: Can be repeated multiple times for credit

title: Community Arts Performance Practicum
description: Provides practical experience as a participant in a Department of Performing Arts community arts initiative. Includes involvement with off campus activities with community members under faculty supervision and direction.
repeat_status: Can be repeated multiple times for credit

title: Independent Study in Performing Arts
description: Self-directed within the area of study requiring intermittent consultation with a designated instructor.

title: Film Photography I
description: A lecture-laboratory course in black-and-white photography. This class works to develop visual literacy and a comprehensive understanding of the camera and darkroom.
restrictions: Can enroll if major is PHTO.

title: Digital Photography I
description: The objective of this course is to give you an introduction to the technical skills necessary to use computers, equipment, and software as a means of visually communicating your photographic ideas.

title: Digital Photographic Post Production
description: This course is an introduction to the manipulation and output of files using Photoshop and Lightroom. Skills acquired include working with RAW files, density, contrast and color correction, basic retouching, compositing of image, type and color elements along with special effects and output via inkjet printer. A digital point and shoot camera or DSLR, 16 megapixels or greater is required that is capable of shooting in RAW file format.

title: Intermediate Photography
description: Continues the aesthetic and technical investigations of black and white photography begun in PHTO 110 through a mix of lectures, slide discussions, analytical and creative projects, and group critiques. For PHTO Majors, a manual 35mm film camera is required. For PHTO Minors & non-majors a digital point and shoot camera or DSLR, 16 megapixels or higher is required. Cameras that are capable of shooting in RAW format are strongly recommended.

title: Film Photography II
description: Continues the aesthetic and technical investigations of black and white film photography begun in PHTO 120 through a mix of lectures, slide discussions, analytical and creative projects, and group critiques.

title: Studio Lighting Techniques
description: This course introduces studio photography practices with a focus on creating a portfolio. Continues utilization of the digital camera. Examines augmenting available light, and artificial lighting techniques. Provides basic approaches to studio photography and how to apply them outside the studio with available materials.

title: Looking at Photographs
description: Millions of photographic images are produced every day. How do we sort through all those images and make sense of them? This course investigates the many ways photographs inform culture, as well as the means with which culture influences the images we create and absorb every day. We examine common themes and techniques that are used in all aspects of contemporary photography and investigate their origins. The course challenges and sharpens each student's ability to read photographs, greatly enhancing their visual literacy.

title: Color Photography I
description: This course will introduce students to the foundations of color photography. It is a lecture-laboratory course that combines the visual, technical, and communicative properties of color photography with comprehensive color digital workflow experience. Students will begin to master the techniques of properly color balancing their prints and develop a sense of how to use color. It is important to grasp the foundations of color photography, but it is equally important to understand the aesthetic implications that using color entails.

title: Large Format Photography
description: Provides a thorough exploration of large-format camera techniques and large-format film exposure/development techniques including the zone system. Introduces the aesthetic of the large-format black-and-white photograph and expands the student's vision of the potential of the photographic image.

title: Studio Photography
description: Introduces professional studio photography practices. Continues utilization of the digital camera. Examines artifical lighting techniques and provides context for exploration of the studio as a creative photographic environment.

title: Photojournalism
description: Approaches the subject of photojournalism through lectures on its history and current practices and through application. Considers the documentary genre of photography in general.

title: Digital Photography II
description: Explores the digital image within the context of photographic practice. Examines current capabilities and future potentials in image capture, manipulation, output, and dissemination. Projects include utilization of image-manipulation programs, direct digital cameras, and hybrid film/digital approaches. Addresses aesthetic, conceptual, and professional issues.

title: Fine Black & White Printing
description: Explores the aesthetic of the fine black-and-white print, including issues of print scale, tonality, surface quality, toning, and archival techniques. Uses zone-system analysis to optimize the relationship of the negative and the print.

title: History of Photography I
description: Provides an overview of the history of photography from 1839 to approximately 1930, including technological developments, aesthetic trends, theoretical and philosophical understandings, and effects on society and culture at large.

title: History of Photography II
description: Provides an overview of the history of photography from approximately 1930 to the present, including technological developments, aesthetic trends, theoretical and philosophical understandings, and effects on society and culture at large.

title: Internship
description: Incorporates a nonpaying internship in the field of photography for academic credit. An initial informational sheet on the internship and a final paper on the experience are required. May be repeated for credit. Department permission required.
repeat_status: Can be repeated multiple times for credit
restrictions: Can enroll if major is PHTO.

title: Advanced Studio Photography
description: An advanced studio photography class that will teach the student the workflow associated with high-end digital studio capture. The class will also cover various advanced studio lighting techniques. The development of a personal portfolio of work produced in the studio will be required by all students.
restrictions: Can enroll if major is PHTO.

title: Special Topics in Geoscience
description: Topics decided upon by faculty will vary within the area of study.
repeat_status: Can be repeated multiple times for credit

title: Portraiture
description: This course is devoted to the development of a single project. The course will deal in depth with issues of format, lighting and composition. The course will address ethical and legal matters in photographic portraiture. An overview of the history of photographic portrait will be covered.

title: Digital Photography III
description: This class will build on intermediate Photoshop skills while exploring the new field of building a photographic image by using more than one frame or multiple elements. Students will be expected to produce a body of work using the skills learned. Large format printing will be stressed.
restrictions: Can enroll if major is PHTO and classification is Junior or Senior.

title: Advanced Photography
description: Extends study and experimentation in studio, color, and historical photography. Examines non-silver and non-traditional photographic technologies.
restrictions: Can enroll if major is PHTO.

title: Junior Project in Photography
description: Integrates the technical and conceptual understandings that the student has acquired in photography through development of a personally defined photographic project. Students will meet in weekly seminars to plan, discuss, and critique in-progress work.
restrictions: Can enroll if major is PHTO and classification is Junior.

title: Photography and Business
description: Seminar course with invited professionals from the photographic and business fields. Helps prospective photographers understand legal aspects of photography, freelance business practices, and potential employment possibilities and expectations.

title: History of Contemporary Photography
description: The course will focus on aesthetic and conceptual development in contemporary photographic practice. Through lectures, field trips and in-class discussions, students will learn concepts and visual trends employed in photography since 1970. Topics covered include 19th and 20th century influences, multi-cultural interpretation of genres, new approaches to representation of self.

title: Photography Production
description: The objective of this course is to introduce prospective photographers to production practices. Topics covered will include the varied roles of a photographer/director, production elements, treatment writing, roles of production crews, interpreting layouts and concepts, and approaches to production in contemporary times.
restrictions: Can enroll if major is PHTO and classification is Senior.

title: Landscape Photography
description: This class is designed to explore the rich tradition and history of the landscape photograph and how to visually translate the contemporary landscape.
repeat_status: Can be repeated multiple times for credit
restrictions: Can enroll if major is PHTO and classification is Junior or Senior.

title: Fashion Photography
description: The objective of this course is for students to become familiar with both the aesthetics and techniques involved in the production of fashion photographs. In addition, the history of fashion photography will be covered.
restrictions: Can enroll if major is PHTO and classification is Junior or Senior.

title: Palladium Printing
description: This class explores the technical and aesthetic aspects of the 19th century, hand-coated palladium and platinum printing processes. Students will use large format negatives to produce a body of work. This course will include hand-coating techniques, paper and chemistry options.
restrictions: Can enroll if major is PHTO and classification is Junior or Senior.

title: Print and Web Portfolio Development
description: This course is designed to prepare students to enter the commercial market. Topics covered will include the definition and marketing of personal visual style, identity and cohesion, and contemporary self-promotion practices.
restrictions: Can enroll if major is PHTO and classification is Senior.

title: Marketing for Photographers
description: The objective of this course is to give students practical skills about marketing, design, and production of materials you will need as a photographer. Discussions and demonstrations will show you how to use print, web, and other technologies to promote your photography.
restrictions: Can enroll if major is PHTO and classification is Junior or Senior.

title: Senior Thesis in Photography I
description: Integrates the technical and conceptual understandings that the student has acquired in photography through development of a personally defined photographic project. Students will meet in weekly seminars to plan, discuss, and critique in-progress work.

title: Senior Thesis in Photography II
description: Integrates the technical and conceptual understandings that the student has acquired in photography through development of a personally defined photographic project. Students will meet in weekly seminars to plan, discuss, and critique in-progress work.

title: Senior Thesis in Photography III
description: Integrates the technical and conceptual understandings that the student has acquired in photography through development of a personally defined photographic project. Students will meet in weekly seminars to plan, discuss, and critique in-progress work.
restrictions: Can enroll if major is PHTO and classification is Senior.

title: Exhibition
description: This course is devoted to the final development of your senior thesis project. We will be preparing your work for the final senior thesis exhibition. This will include the final selection of work, sequencing, printing and framing of the work.

title: Independent Study in Photography
description: Self-directed within the area of study requiring intermittent consultation with a designated instructor.
repeat_status: Can be repeated multiple times for credit

title: History and Analysis of Product Design
description: This class studies the chronological context of the development of the product design profession, relating it to the social, cultural and economic events that helped shape our modern day society. Studies are focuses on major industrial designers and innovations. This course has both a project and written analysis paper component.

title: Applied Making I
description: This course introduces the development of rapid study models and mid-fidelity prototypes related to product design. Students, through a series of exercises, build study models of products to professional standards of accuracy and finish, with an emphasis on rapid development. Aspects of workshop practice and safety are emphasized.

title: Form Studio
description: This course is the basic introduction to the study of form and abstract visual relationships. It explores the issues concerning the organization of multiple elements of a 3-dimensional composition and form as it relates to the natural world. Its emphasis is on the abstract, rather than the literal, to remove stereotypical object identification.

title: Intro to Product Design
description: This course introduces students to basic product design techniques. It combines lectures, demonstrations, discussions, and problem-solving exercises exploring product design as a creative process in the production of simple objects. Students develop a command of product development, skills in modeling and communication of their novel solutions.

title: Design Thinking in Product Design
description: This course is an integrated lecture/lab introducing principles and theories of product design, systematic design process, problem-solving, decision making and design as authorship. The course uses design research methods, and topical design issues to explore and experience design thinking.

title: Product Design Form Studio
description: This course uses principles of visual design in the organization of physical elements and analysis of form. Building on abstract relationships, natural inspiration, and the study of visual reference, students develop a sensitivity to form language, semantics, materials, and aesthetics of 3D objects of design. They learn to synthesize this abstract language into functional objects.

title: Computer Aided Imagining in Product Design
description: This is an applied computer class in which students pursue the development of design projects using current product design photo-realistic rendering softward for object design and three-dimensional modeling of products applicable to rapid prototyping.
restrictions: Can enroll if major is PROD.

title: Product Design Process Studio
description: In this course students are presented complex design issues in mass-produced objects. Students develop an understanding of the product development process focusing on the designers skills and technical knowledge to formulate appropriate design solutions. Students practice collaboration of ideas with engineers, marketing, users and shareholders.

title: Applied Design Visualization
description: This course will provide students with schemas and strategies for using visualization as a thinking tool, as well as persuasive techniques for communicating design intent. It will put into practice the essential techniques that product designers use to think and communicate visually.

title: Smart Product Design
description: To explore ideas around tangible interaction, this course will introduce the smart product development process and combine basic microcontroller programming with digital application development to conceptualize responsive products, environments, and/or materials. Students will design and prototype functional devices that operate using embedded technologies that enhance user experience.

title: Seminar Professional Landscape
description: In this course students explore current trends in the product design profession today. Students will research and present insights into important design issues, trends, and criticism in contemporary product design. Through extensive readings and discussions, students develop an understanding of the relationship of product design to society and culture.
restrictions: Can enroll if major is PROD.

title: Applied Materials in Product Design
description: The course emphasizes the practical relationship between product design and the manufacturing industry and the technical considerations that influence the choice of material and process for small batch and mass production.
restrictions: Can enroll if major is PROD.

title: Introduction to CAD Product Design
description: Introduces the creation and manipulation of three-dimensional digital models and the resultant two-dimensional drawings using computer techniques.

title: Visual Communication for Product Design
description: This course explores the various types of visual communication and presentation fundamentals applying the layout and composition type, color, images, and graphic assets used in product and visual presentation applications.

title: Soft Goods for Product Design
description: This course combines studio and lecture to introduce students to a variety of soft material structures and soft fabrication methods, and guides them towards purposeful use and innovative applications. Through hands-on prompted experimentation, materials research, materials presentations, instructive editing, and group critique, students will explore the unique role of soft goods in contemporary design.

title: Speaker Making
description: This course will focus on the art and design of building quality speakers. Students will be expected to design and build either a bluetooth speaker or a set of bookshelf speakers. Students will learn how to select drivers, crossovers as well as learn how to calculate the right size enclosure to get the optimum sound out of your speakers. Students will be expected to make a well-crafted and good sounding set of speakers as a final assignment.

title: Interdisciplinary Product Design Studio
description: Through a focused design project, students of various backgrounds and departments collaborate on complex design issues as they seek to create an appropriate and novel solution to the assigned design problem. Bringing both the PROD majors and PROD minors together, students work as teams through the product development cycle.

title: Applied Human Centered Design
description: This course explores the physical, psychological, perceptual, and behavioral characteristics of humans. Through a series of lectures and projects, this information is applied to the field of product design to develop safe and effective products.

title: Experimental Design
description: This course is a study into the experimentation and rapid three-dimensional visualization and manipulation of material, form, and function of designed objects no larger than the human body. Students will apply iterative hands-on design process to work through guided assignments to create self-directed project ideas for a variety of contexts. Students will deconstruct preconceived notions of everyday materials, objects, and functions—resolving ideas through technical problem-solving, analog and digital manufacturing, and various CAD software and digital tools.

title: Applied Design Research
description: This course covers diverse theories and methods for conducting product design research. Emphasis is given to understanding quantitative and qualitative research methods and the role the designer in synthesizing and applying research as a critical part of the design process. This course combines writing and short projects.
restrictions: Can enroll if major is PROD.

title: Design for Manufacturing
description: In Design for Manufacturing, students will have the opportunity to translate a conceptualized idea and design into a portfolio ready, high fidelity prototype. Using methods of contemporary production, each student will undergo the process of designing a product and developing presentable drawings that will be used to fabricate their parts for final assembly. Within this course, there will be an emphasis on computer aided systems that augment conceptual exploration and rapid manufacturing techniques. Vocabulary will be developed via an understanding of and engagement with tooling capabilities, CAD modeling, critical dialogue and investigating the relationship between design and fabrication.

title: Research Synthesis Studio
description: In this first of two senior studios, students apply their skills to initiate research on an opportunity of their selection. Under supervision, students demonstrate control of applied design research and synthesis. This course focuses on the information gathering, study, and analysis that product designers do to inspire and inform themselves.
restrictions: Can enroll if major is PROD.

title: Create Build Studio
description: In this second of two studios, students apply their skills to develop a solution based on the research conducted in the previous studio. Under supervision, students will demonstrate control of the product design process in the producation of a novel and appropriate user-focused solution.
restrictions: Can enroll if major is PROD.

title: Professional Practice in Product Design
description: This course provides information about career planning and job seeking, including the development of cover letters, resumes, online and physical portfolios and the interview process. Practicing design professionals serve as guest speakers and conduct mock interviews to address topics relevant to the practice of product design.
restrictions: Can enroll if major is PROD.

title: Exhibition Studio
description: This final studio is a culmination of the educational experience in the production of a senior exhibition highlighting the students' accomplishments. Under supervision, students work together to demonstrate control of all aspects of the design process and visual communication in the production of a graduation exhibition.
restrictions: Can enroll if major is PROD.

title: Independent Study in Product Design
description: Self-directed within the area of study requiring intermittent consultation with a designated instructor.
repeat_status: Can be repeated multiple times for credit
